ended.note: Transmitted recall by note from London

chief.note: Resident at London after 1785. Adams also received a second set of instructions dated August 16, 1781.

started.note: Presented as Charge d'affaires ad interim on

chief.note: John Adams, before leaving The Hague at the end of his longest period of residence there, presented Charles W.F. Dumas as Charge d'Affaires ad interim. Dumas, although holding no commission from the United States, continued to act in this capacity, except during Adams's later visits to the Netherlands, until 1790.
Continued to serve, without reaccreditation, after the proclamation of the Batavian Republic.
Commissioned to the Batavian Republic.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on November 30, 1818, after confirmation.

Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation. That commission is not of record, but is enclosed with an instruction of March 19, 1840.

The record copy of Folsom's credentials is dated May 4, but the date is probably erroneous, since the Senate confirmed Folsom’s nomination on May 14, 1850.

ended.note: In anticipation of German occupation, the Government left the Netherlands on

chief.note: Gordon closed the Legation on July 15, 1940, and left post on July 16, 1940. Rudolf E. Schoenfeld established the Legation near the Government of the Netherlands established in the United Kingdom, making his initial call as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim on Aug 15, 1940.
Schoenfeld established the Legation near the Government of the Netherlands in the United Kingdom.

ended.note: Promoted to Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary

started.note: Legation raised to Embassy status and formally received on

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on January 26, 1954, after confirmation.
Elected on June 23, 1785, to be Minister Plenipotentiary to the United Netherlands; declined appointment.
Elected on July 5, 1785, to be Minister Plenipotentiary to the United Netherlands; declined appointment.
